Position and Terrain

Position Module - Immutable Position Value Object

This module demonstrates the Immutable Pattern by providing an immutable coordinate representation for the grid-based world.

Design Patterns:

  • Immutable Pattern: Position objects cannot be modified after creation

SOLID Principles:

  • Single Responsibility: Manages only coordinate representation and operations

  • Open/Closed: Extensible through new methods without modifying existing ones

class world.position.Position[source]

Bases: object

Immutable value object representing a position in 2D grid space.

The frozen=True parameter makes this class immutable, preventing modification after instantiation. This ensures thread-safety and predictable behavior when positions are shared across the system.

x

The x-coordinate in the grid

Type:

int

y

The y-coordinate in the grid

Type:

int

Examples

>>> pos1 = Position(5, 10)
>>> pos2 = Position(8, 14)
>>> distance = pos1.distance_to(pos2)
>>> neighbors = pos1.get_neighbors()
x: int
y: int
distance_to(other)[source]

Calculate Euclidean distance to another position.

Parameters:

other (Position) – The target position

Returns:

The Euclidean distance between positions

Return type:

float

Examples

>>> pos1 = Position(0, 0)
>>> pos2 = Position(3, 4)
>>> pos1.distance_to(pos2)
5.0
manhattan_distance_to(other)[source]

Calculate Manhattan (grid) distance to another position.

Manhattan distance is the sum of absolute differences in coordinates, representing the distance when movement is restricted to grid lines.

Parameters:

other (Position) – The target position

Returns:

The Manhattan distance between positions

Return type:

int

Examples

>>> pos1 = Position(0, 0)
>>> pos2 = Position(3, 4)
>>> pos1.manhattan_distance_to(pos2)
7
get_neighbors(include_diagonals=False)[source]

Get all neighboring positions.

Parameters:

include_diagonals (bool) – If True, includes diagonal neighbors (8 total). If False, only includes cardinal directions (4 total).

Returns:

List of neighboring positions

Return type:

List[Position]

Examples

>>> pos = Position(5, 5)
>>> len(pos.get_neighbors(include_diagonals=False))
4
>>> len(pos.get_neighbors(include_diagonals=True))
8
is_adjacent_to(other, include_diagonals=False)[source]

Check if another position is adjacent to this one.

Parameters:

  • other (Position) – The position to check

  • include_diagonals (bool) – If True, diagonal positions count as adjacent

Returns:

True if positions are adjacent, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

is_within_bounds(width, height)[source]

Check if this position is within given bounds.

Parameters:

  • width (int) – Maximum x-coordinate (exclusive)

  • height (int) – Maximum y-coordinate (exclusive)

Returns:

True if position is within bounds [0, width) x [0, height)

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> pos = Position(5, 5)
>>> pos.is_within_bounds(10, 10)
True
>>> pos.is_within_bounds(5, 5)
False

Convert position to a tuple.

Returns:

The (x, y) coordinates as a tuple

Return type:

Tuple[int, int]

  • x (int)

  • y (int)

Terrain Module - Immutable Terrain Type System

This module demonstrates the Immutable Pattern for terrain data. TerrainType objects are immutable and shared, ensuring consistent behavior across the simulation.

Design Patterns:

  • Immutable Pattern: TerrainProperties cannot be modified after creation

SOLID Principles:

  • Single Responsibility: Manages only terrain type information

  • Open/Closed: New terrain types can be added without modifying existing code

  • Dependency Inversion: Depends on abstract enum, not concrete implementations

class world.terrain.TerrainTypeEnum[source]

Bases: Enum

Enumeration of all terrain types in the world.

Each terrain type has different properties affecting resource generation, movement speed, and agent behavior.

PLAINS

Open grassland, easy traversal, moderate resources

FOREST

Dense woods, slower movement, high food resources

MOUNTAIN

Rocky terrain, difficult traversal, high material resources

WATER

Lakes and rivers, blocks most movement, water resource source

DESERT

Arid land, harsh conditions, scarce resources

PLAINS = 'plains'
FOREST = 'forest'
MOUNTAIN = 'mountain'
WATER = 'water'
DESERT = 'desert'
class world.terrain.TerrainProperties[source]

Bases: object

Immutable properties associated with a terrain type.

The frozen=True parameter ensures these properties cannot be modified after creation, maintaining consistency across the simulation.

terrain_type

The type of terrain

Type:

TerrainTypeEnum

movement_cost

Movement cost multiplier (1.0 = normal, >1.0 = slower)

Type:

float

traversable

Whether agents can move through this terrain

Type:

bool

resource_fertility

Multiplier for resource generation (0.0-2.0)

Type:

float

description

Human-readable description of the terrain

Type:

str

Examples

>>> props = TerrainProperties(
...     terrain_type=TerrainTypeEnum.FOREST,
...     movement_cost=1.5,
...     traversable=True,
...     resource_fertility=1.8,
...     description="Dense forest with abundant resources"
... )
terrain_type: TerrainTypeEnum
movement_cost: float
traversable: bool
resource_fertility: float
description: str

ValueError – If properties are outside valid ranges

Return type:

None

Return type:

class world.terrain.TerrainFactory[source]

Bases: object

Factory for creating and caching immutable TerrainProperties.

This class ensures that only one instance of each terrain type’s properties exists, supporting the immutable pattern through caching.

The factory pattern allows centralized creation of terrain properties while maintaining immutability guarantees.

classmethod get_properties(terrain_type)[source]

Get the immutable properties for a given terrain type.

This method implements lazy initialization and caching to ensure only one instance of each TerrainProperties exists.

Parameters:

terrain_type (TerrainTypeEnum) – The terrain type to look up

Returns:

Immutable properties for the terrain type

Return type:

TerrainProperties

Examples

>>> props = TerrainFactory.get_properties(TerrainTypeEnum.FOREST)
>>> print(props.movement_cost)
1.5
classmethod register_custom_terrain(terrain_type, properties)[source]

Register custom terrain properties.

Allows extension of terrain types without modifying existing code, demonstrating the Open/Closed Principle.

Parameters:

  • terrain_type (TerrainTypeEnum) – The terrain type to register

  • properties (TerrainProperties) – The immutable properties to associate

Raises:

ValueError – If terrain type already exists in cache

Return type:

None

Note

This should only be called during initialization. Once the simulation starts, terrain properties should not change.

classmethod get_all_terrain_types()[source]

Get all registered terrain types and their properties.

Returns:

Mapping of all terrain types

Return type:

Dict[TerrainTypeEnum, TerrainProperties]

Generators Module

World Generation

Config Module - Immutable World Configuration

This module provides immutable configuration objects for world generation, demonstrating the Immutable Pattern.

Design Patterns:

  • Immutable Pattern: Configuration cannot be modified after creation

SOLID Principles:

  • Single Responsibility: Manages only configuration data

  • Open/Closed: New configuration fields can be added via subclassing

class generators.config.WorldConfig[source]

Bases: object

Immutable configuration for world generation.

The frozen=True parameter ensures this configuration cannot be modified after creation, preventing accidental changes that could lead to inconsistent world generation.

width

World grid width

Type:

int

height

World grid height

Type:

int

resource_density

Resource generation density (0.0-1.0)

Type:

float

seed

Random seed for reproducible generation

Type:

Optional[int]

terrain_distribution

Terrain type probabilities

Type:

Dict[str, float]

width: int
height: int
resource_density: float = 0.3
seed: Optional[int] = None
terrain_distribution: Optional[Dict[str, float]] = None
__post_init__()[source]

Validate configuration after initialization.

Raises:

ValueError – If configuration values are invalid

Return type:

None

with_width(width)[source]

Create a new config with different width.

Parameters:

width (int) – New width

Returns:

New configuration instance

Return type:

WorldConfig

Note

Since config is immutable, this creates a new instance.

Examples

>>> config = WorldConfig(100, 100)
>>> new_config = config.with_width(200)
